body.p: DEDICATION OF PLEASANT VIEW SCHOOL The Pleasant View school building, which was recently completed, will be formally dedicated Friday of this week. Everybody is welcome to attend the dedication, which will be held at 4 p. m. Friday. The building will be open for inspection during the afternoon, and all are invited to go through it and see what a fine improvement and addition it will be to the facilities of School District No. 4. A special invitation is extended to the members of the district to look over the building. The improvement was made under a WPA grant, and the former two rooms were refinished, two new rooms larger than the others, added, and a full basement put under the building. There is an automatic control heating system and the building is modem in every way and accord- ing to state requirements. Play- ground equipment has been installed. Hot lunches are served in the basement. Classes have been held in the old building, in the church, and in the town hall for the past two years due to over-crowding. It was a much needed addition and improvement. State Superintendent John Calla- han, of Madison, will be chief speaker at the dedication. Miss Grace Webb, county superintendent, E. S. Jedney, Mr. Hughes of Sparta, engineer in charge of the job, and possibly others will appear on the program. Harold Turner is chairman of the general arrangement committee. The P. T. A. of Pleasant View is taking a prominent part in arrange- ments for the day, and will serve hot lunches during the afternoon and eve- ning. There will be a program both afternoon and evening. There are 144 pupils enrolled in the school, and four teachers Coyle Radcliffe, Miss Erika Balsiger, Mrs. Olga Waldum and Miss Cora Gut- knecht.
